repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and the Caribbean - OECS
            Telecommunications Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey a satisfactory
            project outcome, highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts.
            Notwithstanding, some lessons of experience are suggested.
            The practice worldwide regarding telecommunications policy
            and regulatory issues is that it is to be addressed on a
            national level; however, a regional approach was seen as
            viable, since the telecommunications issues facing each
            island were similar, and there was firm commitment from the
            Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) Heads of
            Government, to liberalize telecommunications services and
            address telecommunications regionally. This allows small
            countries to benefit from the shared fixed costs of
            regulatory institutions. Nevertheless, the approach
            concerning spectrum management, and monitoring prior to the
            project was rudimentary, and would not have been sufficient
            to support the expansion of wireless services, had it not
            been for the increased capabilities accorded by the Radio
            Spectrum Monitoring and Management System (RSMMS), essential
            during rapid growth in the use of the spectrum. A competent
            spectrum management and monitoring system is necessary for
            an expanding, modern telecommunications sector. Moreover, it
            is highlighted that coordination of a regional project is
            complex, and stretches very thinly both project management,
            and supervision resources. Even with the best intentions,
            there were delays, particularly in obtaining signatures from
            the five countries on the two extensions of the closing
            date. However, financing and retention of high caliber
            technical advisor, critical in negotiations with dominant
            operators, proved successful.

Latin America and the Caribbean - OECS
            Telecommunications Reform Project

repnme.cdata!: Reducing telecom costs in the Caribbean

abstracts.cdata!:
As in any society, access to information
            and the ability to communicate are essential if people are
            to participate in economic development. In five countries of
            the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) -
            Dominica, Grenada, St Kitts-Nevis, St. Lucia, and St.
            Vincent - an expensive and erratic telephone system held
            back development as the information age unfolded in the
            1980s and 90s. In 1998, the World Bank helped the OECS
            countries set up a regional telecommunications authority,
            which ultimately negotiated the terms for liberalization of
            the eastern Caribbean's telecom market. So far, the
            telecommunications project has reduced telephone and
            internet charges by nearly half. Lower rates have helped to
            stimulate new, more diverse businesses in these small economies.
